verses.text: The LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
verses.comment: A new section begins; the LORD gives direct revelation to Moses for the people of Israel. See also Ex. 12:1.

verses.text: Speak to the sons of Israel, and say to them: When you enter the land that I am giving you to dwell in,
verses.comment: God’s instructions presume their eventual arrival in the promised land despite the wilderness wanderings. It reinforces the certainty of God's plan.

verses.text: and you offer to the LORD a burnt offering, or a sacrifice, whether to fulfill a vow, or as a freewill offering, or at your appointed feasts, to make a pleasing aroma to the LORD, from the herd or from the flock,
verses.comment: Sacrifices include different types: required, voluntary, and for special festivals. The 'pleasing aroma' is a sign of God’s acceptance of the offering (Eph. 5:2).

verses.text: then the one who brings his offering shall present to the LORD a grain offering, one-tenth of an ephah of fine flour, mixed with a quarter of a hin of oil.
verses.comment: The grain offering complements animal sacrifice, emphasizing the offering of both the fruit of labor and life itself.

verses.text: And you shall offer with the burnt offering or the sacrifice a quarter of a hin of wine as a drink offering for each lamb.
verses.comment: The drink offering, poured out, prefigures Christ’s blood poured out for us. See Matt. 26:27-28.

verses.text: Or for a ram, you shall present a grain offering, two-tenths of an ephah of fine flour mixed with a third of a hin of oil.
verses.comment: Larger offerings for larger animals—demonstrating proportional sacrifice and devotion.

verses.text: And for the drink offering, you shall offer a third of a hin of wine, a pleasing aroma to the LORD.
verses.comment: The wine offering enhances the symbolism of joy, blessing, and fellowship with God.

verses.text: When you prepare a bull as a burnt offering or as a sacrifice, to fulfill a vow, or for peace offerings to the LORD,
verses.comment: The various purposes for sacrifice align with different needs: atonement, thanksgiving, and covenant.

verses.text: then he shall bring with the bull a grain offering of three-tenths of an ephah of fine flour mixed with half a hin of oil,
verses.comment: The accompanying grain and oil portions scale up for larger sacrifices, teaching fullness of worship.

verses.text: and you shall offer for the drink offering half a hin of wine as an offering by fire, a pleasing aroma to the LORD.
verses.comment: The wine poured out hints toward later sacramental undertones (cf. John 2:3-11; 1 Cor. 10:16).

verses.text: Thus it shall be done for each bull, or each ram, or each of the male lambs or the goats.
verses.comment: Consistent offerings promote orderly, unified worship.

verses.text: According to the number that you prepare, so shall you do for each, according to their number.
verses.comment: This verse repeats the principle: all sacrifices must be accompanied by proper offerings, showing completeness.

verses.text: All native-born Israelites shall do these things in this way, in presenting an offering by fire, a pleasing aroma to the LORD.
verses.comment: All born Israelites have the same responsibility in worship—a sign of unity and communal identity.

verses.text: And if a stranger is sojourning with you, or anyone living among you through the generations, and he offers an offering by fire, a pleasing aroma to the LORD, as you do, so shall he do.
verses.comment: Inclusivity in worship: even ‘sojourners’ can participate, illustrating God's desire for the nations’ inclusion.

verses.text: One statute shall be for you and for the stranger sojourning with you, a perpetual statute throughout your generations. As you are, so shall the sojourner be before the LORD.
verses.comment: This foreshadows God’s plan for unity under one law and covenant for all peoples. See Gal. 3:28.

verses.text: There shall be one law and one rule for you and for the sojourner who lives among you.
verses.comment: God’s people are not divided. All are called to the same covenant relationship and obligations: a shadow of the Church’s unity.

verses.text: The LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
verses.comment: A new oracle begins. The repetition points to the seriousness of these instructions.

verses.text: Speak to the sons of Israel and say to them, When you come into the land to which I bring you,
verses.comment: Again, God’s faithfulness to the promise is highlighted. The law is given in view of living in the land—a key covenant motif.

verses.text: then it shall be, when you eat the bread of the land, that you shall offer up a contribution to the LORD.
verses.comment: Acknowledging God as the giver: the first part of the harvest is set aside for Him. Anticipates Christ as the ‘firstfruits’ (1 Cor. 15:20).

verses.text: You shall offer up a cake from the first of your dough as a contribution; as you offer the contribution from the threshing floor, so you shall present it.
verses.comment: Dedication of material goods teaches offering the best to God first, a prefigurement of spiritual sacrifice in the New Covenant.

verses.text: From the first of your dough you shall give to the LORD a contribution throughout your generations.
verses.comment: An enduring practice, signifying ongoing gratitude and faithfulness.

verses.text: But if you unintentionally fail and do not observe all these commandments which the LORD has spoken to Moses,
verses.comment: God distinguishes unintentional from deliberate sin, emphasizing His mercy and justice.

verses.text: even all that the LORD has commanded you by the hand of Moses, from the day that the LORD commanded and onward, throughout your generations,
verses.comment: This encompasses all of God’s law, meaning all generations are held to these standards of faithfulness.

verses.text: then if it was done unintentionally, without the knowledge of the congregation, all the congregation shall offer one bull from the herd for a burnt offering, a pleasing aroma to the LORD, with its grain offering and its drink offering, according to the regulation, and one male goat for a sin offering.
verses.comment: Forgiveness comes through prescribed sacrifice: a teaching about collective responsibility and the need for mediation.

verses.text: The priest shall make atonement for all the congregation of the sons of Israel, and they shall be forgiven, because it was unintentional. And they shall bring their offering, a sacrifice by fire to the LORD, and their sin offering before the LORD, for their mistake.
verses.comment: Note the role of the priest as intercessor—pointing ahead to Christ’s unique priesthood (Heb. 7:23-27).

verses.text: And all the congregation of the sons of Israel shall be forgiven, and the stranger who sojourns among them, because all the people did it unintentionally.
verses.comment: Collective forgiveness includes both Israelites and sojourners, underlining the inclusiveness and mercy present in God’s law.

verses.text: If one person sins unintentionally, he shall offer a female goat a year old for a sin offering.
verses.comment: Personal responsibility and personal atonement—reflecting both individual and corporate dimensions of sin and forgiveness.

verses.text: The priest shall make atonement before the LORD for the person who makes a mistake by sinning unintentionally, and he shall be forgiven.
verses.comment: The priesthood mediates God’s mercy. Christ, our eternal high priest, fulfills this role perfectly (Heb. 9:11-14).

verses.text: You shall have one law for him who does anything unintentionally, for him who is native among the sons of Israel, and for the stranger who sojourns among them.
verses.comment: God's justice and mercy apply to all people under His covenant, providing a foundation for future unity among believers.

verses.text: But the person who does anything with a high hand, whether he is native or a sojourner, insults the LORD, and that person shall be cut off from among his people.
verses.comment: 'High hand' means a deliberate, willful sin—showing contempt for God’s rule. The consequence is exclusion from the community, a theme Christ warns against in Matt. 12:31-32.

verses.text: Because he has despised the word of the LORD and has broken His commandment, that person shall be utterly cut off; his guilt shall be upon him.
verses.comment: Willful rebellion breaks fellowship with God and community. Yet, God’s mercy is greater for those who repent (cf. Luke 15:11-32).

verses.text: While the sons of Israel were in the wilderness, they found a man gathering sticks on the Sabbath day.
verses.comment: An incident illustrating the seriousness of Sabbath observance, referencing the fourth commandment.

verses.text: Those who found him gathering sticks brought him to Moses and Aaron, and to all the congregation.
verses.comment: Community accountability—a model for the community of believers upholding God’s commands together (cf. Matt. 18:15-17).

verses.text: They put him under guard, because it was not clear what should be done to him.
verses.comment: The law was not explicit on punishment; they sought God’s guidance—a theme for discernment and dependence on ordained leaders.

verses.text: Then the LORD said to Moses, 'The man must surely be put to death; all the congregation shall stone him outside the camp.'
verses.comment: Sabbath-breaking brings a severe penalty, signifying the holiness of God’s law and of sacred time. It foreshadows the spiritual ‘death’ from mortal sin, while later, Christ brings mercy and restoration (John 8:3-11).

verses.text: So all the congregation brought him outside the camp and stoned him with stones, just as the LORD had commanded Moses.
verses.comment: Corporate obedience to God’s explicit command, even when difficult—echoed in the New Covenant’s call for holiness and discipline (1 Cor. 5:13).

verses.text: The LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
verses.comment: A new instruction begins—emphasizing continual openness to God’s revelation.

verses.text: Speak to the sons of Israel, and tell them to make tassels on the corners of their garments throughout their generations, and to put a blue cord on each tassel of the corners.
verses.comment: The tassels, with a blue thread, are reminders of God’s commandments. The blue may signify heaven or royalty—anticipating the new law written on the heart by the Spirit.

verses.text: And it shall be a tassel for you to look at and remember all the commandments of the LORD, to do them, and not to follow after your own heart and your own eyes, after which you used to go astray,
verses.comment: Visible reminders shape actions and thinking, supporting the need for physical signs in worship—an enduring part of Christian spirituality.

verses.text: so that you may remember and do all my commandments, and be holy to your God.
verses.comment: Holiness is the call of God’s people, internalized and visible—ultimately fulfilled in Christ (1 Pet. 1:15-16).

verses.text: I am the LORD your God, who brought you out of the land of Egypt, to be your God. I am the LORD your God.
verses.comment: This covenant declaration is central: God redeems and claims a people for Himself, fulfilled in the redemption won by Christ.
